ticket.tag: activerecord bugmash database models performance validations
ticket.title: Reduce queries in uniqueness validation
ticket.original-body: When you're doing a uniqueness validation, you don't have to do it if the value haven't changed. Even if it's nil, because the validation should be done by the presence validation.
ticket.latest-body: When you're doing a uniqueness validation, you don't have to do it if the value haven't changed. Even if it's nil, because the validation should be done by the presence validation.
ticket.original-body-html: When you're doing a uniqueness validation, you don't have to do it if the value haven't changed. Even if it's nil, because the validation should be done by the presence validation.

version.body: When you're doing a uniqueness validation, you don't have to do it if the value haven't changed. Even if it's nil, because the validation should be done by the presence validation.
version.body-html: When you're doing a uniqueness validation, you don't have to do it if the value haven't changed. Even if it's nil, because the validation should be done by the presence validation.

version.title: Reduce queries in uniqueness validation

version.tag: activerecord database models performance validations
version.title: Reduce queries in uniqueness validation

version.body: This is interesting. I think in general the approach of not revalidating attributes that haven't changed is probably an optimization worth pursuing. Uniqueness is an odd duck tho, since it's relative to external state. I'm also not sure what you should do if the scope value has changed when the validated attribute has not. Keep working on it though!
version.body-html: This is interesting. I think in general the approach of not revalidating attributes that haven't changed is probably an optimization worth pursuing. Uniqueness is an odd duck tho, since it's relative to external state. I'm also not sure what you should do if the scope value has changed when the validated attribute has not. Keep working on it though!
version.tag: activerecord database models performance validations
version.title: Reduce queries in uniqueness validation

version.body:
__Uniqueness is an odd duck tho, since it's relative to external state.__
I think the validation for uniqueness should always be executed, even when the attribute hasn't changed for this reason.
version.body-html:
Uniqueness is an odd duck tho, since it's relative to external state.

I think the validation for uniqueness should always be executed, even when the attribute hasn't changed for this reason.
version.tag: activerecord database models performance validations
version.title: Reduce queries in uniqueness validation

version.body:
I really don't think so. If the attribute was correctly saved (it was unique before), and it has not changed, then, doesn't matter the external state (that if was changed, was compared to the current object).
I just found a problem in my approach, that is when the scope changes (and I'm not validating this). I mean: I have a Product that belongs to a group, and the product name must be unique on that group. Then, I scope a validates_uniqueness_of :name to the group. If I change the group of the product, doesn't matter if I changed or not the :name, it must be validated.
Could you describe a concurrent situation where don't validate an attribute that didn't change can cause a problem (that doesn't include the situation above)?
version.body-html:
I really don't think so. If the attribute was correctly saved (it was unique before), and it has not changed, then, doesn't matter the external state (that if was changed, was compared to the current object).

I just found a problem in my approach, that is when the scope changes (and I'm not validating this). I mean: I have a Product that belongs to a group, and the product name must be unique on that group. Then, I scope a validates_uniqueness_of :name to the group. If I change the group of the product, doesn't matter if I changed or not the :name, it must be validated.

Could you describe a concurrent situation where don't validate an attribute that didn't change can cause a problem (that doesn't include the situation above)?
version.tag: activerecord database models performance validations
version.title: Reduce queries in uniqueness validation

version.body:
How about adding support (to all validations which take a *list of columns) for :on => :changed (like :on => :create/:update).
Then people who want to reduce queries and are sure external changes won't screw things up can use it, and the current safe behavior remains for everyone else.
version.body-html:
How about adding support (to all validations which take a *list of columns) for :on => :changed (like :on => :create/:update).

Then people who want to reduce queries and are sure external changes won't screw things up can use it, and the current safe behavior remains for everyone else.
version.tag: activerecord database models performance validations
version.title: Reduce queries in uniqueness validation

version.body: Carlos : I agree with everything Josh said. Also, partial updates can be turned off per model basis. So we should have tests for that, and always execute the query if partial updates are disabled.
version.body-html: Carlos : I agree with everything Josh said. Also, partial updates can be turned off per model basis. So we should have tests for that, and always execute the query if partial updates are disabled.

version.body:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not been commented on for at least three months.
The resources of the Rails core team are limited, and so we are asking for your help. If you can still reproduce this error on the 3-0-stable branch or on master, please reply with all of the information you have about it and add "[state:open]" to your comment. This will reopen the ticket for review. Likewise, if you feel that this is a very important feature for Rails to include, please reply with your explanation so we can consider it.
Thank you for all your contributions, and we hope you will understand this step to focus our efforts where they are most helpful.
